title: Why should I vote Green? Everything you need to know about the Green Party
text:

The Green Party is a smaller party but it got more than a million votes in the 2015 general election. 
It has traditionally been particularly interested in the environment but it has policies on a wide range of issues. 
This article is about the Green Party of England and Wales. The Scottish Green Party is a separate party. 
The Chronicle has launched a Whatsapp group for general election news. To receive daily messages text GE to 07827 937 000. Add the number to your phone contacts book as ‘Chronicle’. Your number won’t be shared with other members of the group. Who is the Green Party leader? 
The Green Party has two leaders - Caroline Lucas and Jonathan Bartley Green Party joint leader Caroline Lucas (Photo: PA) How many seats did the Greens win at the last election? 
The Green Party won one seat in the last general election , which was in 2015. This was the seat of Brighton Pavilion. What are the Green Party’s policies? 
Policies set out in the Green Party manifesto include: Employment 
A universal basic income will be piloted in a government-sponsored scheme, as a “means to increase security and avoid the poverty trap”. 
Phase in a four-day working week, abolish zero-hour contracts, increase the minimum wage to £10 an hour by 2020 and end the gender pay gap. 
Require a minimum of 40% of all public sector company boards to be women. 
Scrap age-related wage bands. 
Introduce a “living rent” through rent controls, bring an end to letting fees. 
Build zero-carbon homes, including 100,000 social rented homes, each year by 2022. 
Reinstate housing benefit for under 21s. 
Inside Politics newsletter sign up A 'Vote Green Party' sign (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Health 
Roll back privatisation of the NHS . 
Introduce mental health training in the public sector, and bring mental health care in line with physical health care. Young people 
Lower the voting age to 16. 
Greater access to free condoms and sexual health clinics. 
Introduce non-biased political education to schools. Read More 
Abolish SATS and reduce class sizes. 
Scrap university tuition fees, fund full student grants. 
Restore the Education Maintenance Allowance (EMA) , put a greater focus on apprenticeships for those aged 16-25. 
General Election 2017 manifestos Brexit 
A referendum on the details of the Brexit deal, with the option to reject and remain in the EU. 
Protect freedom of movement, safeguard human and environmental rights. Environment 
Introduce an Environmental Protection Act to restore the environment, enhance biodiversity and promote sustainable food and farming. 
Invest in flood defences and a programme of home insulation. 
Replace fracking, coal, fuel fossil subsidies and nuclear with renewable energy. 
Action to reduce plastic, including Deposit Return Schemes, with a zero waste target. Transport 
Renationalise the railways and increase bus services and rural areas. 
Phase in free local public transport for young people, students, people with disabilities and older people. 
Invest in regional rail links rather than HS2. 
End subsidies on airline fuel, and cancel all airport expansion. 
Increase incentives to take diesel vehicles off the roads. Tax 
Reinstate the higher level of corporation tax for big businesses and include a wealth tax on the top 1% of earners. 
Introduce a “Robin Hood” tax on high value transactions in the finance sector. Tax inheritance based on the wealth of the recipient. 
Remove VAT from sanitary products. Defence 
Scrap the Trident nuclear deterrent. 
Implement an immigration and asylum system that “recognises and takes responsibility for Britain’s ongoing role in causing the flow of migrants worldwide”. 
End arms sales to “oppressive regimes”. Extremism 
Scrap the “xenophobic” Prevent strategy, instead pursuing community-led approaches to tackling extremism in all forms. Like us on Facebook
